annotation.TEXT: To elaborate a bit more: BrightMan.EXE's Navi chip is basically a full-screen stun move. As mentioned before, stunning chips (aside from Mag-Bomb 3) in this game are almost entirely pointless. What makes this even worse is that BrightMan deals virtually no damage (20, for reference). I'm not exaggerating when I say that his ability chip, RemoPlug, is better. Aside from being able to control its vertical path as it fires, it also hits things multiple times.

Safe to say, I won't be using BrightMan's chip. Instead, lets transition ahead (after some off-screen grinding). The Waterworks area has some of the most annoying enemies in the whole game (or in the very least, they have annoying placements). In regards to this, the Aqua Armor isn't necessary for this section, but it certainly helps.

I'm starting to think Capcom enjoyed re-using elements from the classic series a little too much in this game. Either way, these yoku blocks aren't too bad (despite them being icy). In fact, yoku blocks are actually pretty rare in this game (and do not appear in "almost every stage" as the Mega Man wikia seems to think).

As tempting as it is to use a Program Advance on this thing, I figured it would be better suited for the main boss (even though he presents one of the easiest fights in the game). In any case, NeedleMan's chip is a far better choice here. Even though BrightMan's chip would do the same amount of damage (being amplified thanks to the mini-boss' weakness to electricity), it still takes up a valuable slot in the chip folder - which I would prefer to be used by more useful things.

In case you're wondering: No, the chips it drops aren't particularly helpful either. The mini-Puffys can drop either Bubbler or Bub-V chips (which are normally obtained from the Shrimpy viruses in this area). They don't even drop the Bubble Spread chip, which is what the normal sized version of this virus generally gives you.

Unfortunately, the Double Jump requires 24 MB to set as your default chip. While it is possible to have enough MB by this point in the game...it would involve going to the Bank stage before doing this one (and let's face it: Why would you do that to yourself?). Even more-so, this stage itself has a Reg-Up...directly after a section that would be made much easier by the Double Jump.

Actually, this spot right here is the best place to farm their chips (if their spawn placement doesn't mess up, as you saw there). While I'm doing so, I should note on something that makes the Double Jump so effective: In that it's more of an unlimited air-jump. Essentially, you can use the chip several times in mid-air, allowing you to bypass large sections of levels if you felt inclined to do so (but then again, you'd also be missing out on valuable things like zenny and numerous stat upgrades).

Who here remembers that bubble mini-boss in Rockman 4MI? You know, the one just before the Tetris Devil? This fight is essentially like that one, except the gigantic derp fish here has way too much health for its own good (the same goes for its smaller halves it multiplies into).

I'm going to save you the trip back with a transition effect (I know it's not that far, but this way, I'm sparring you more sloppy playing from your's truly. Hopefully this doesn't continue into the next segment, given...well, it'll become apparent if you don't know already).

To the right is a security cube that stops you from reaching IceMan.EXE. To get the key for it, you need to go into the teleporter and face what is quite possibly one of the most drawn out mini-bosses to ever grace a Mega Man game.

Time for the usual routine: Re-fight the previous boss to get their Navi chip, then stock up for the next area. Unfortunately, the former isn't entirely worth it this time around. Granted, it's necessary to get all the Navi chips if you want to gain access to a secret fight later on, but in terms of overall usefulness? BrightMan.EXE's Navi chip is incredibly sub-par.

Compared to the earlier bosses (and even some of the later ones), IceMan.EXE is by far one of the easiest opponents you'll face in this game. It gets to the point where it's almost unnecessary to use battle chips against him (at least, during your first encounter anyways). Both of his main attacks are easy enough to avoid, and he has rather low HP as well.

If I can give a word of advice, it's that you should definitely farm the Penguin enemies. It seems trivial at first, but they actually drop one of the most useful chips in the entire game: The Double Jump. You can only hold 10 of these chips, but even with the limited usage, it's still incredibly helpful (and required if you want to reach certain secrets).
